justification: The article states, “The FFM is most commonly measured through the Revised NEO Personality Inventory, which asks participants to indicate to what extent they agree with various characterizations …” making it clear that the Big-Five construct is operationalized with the NEO-PI-R.

In describing the NEO-PI-R the authors note that it “subsequently reports a population percentile into which the individual falls for each trait (e.g., ‘25th percentile in the population for neuroticism’)” ­— implying that each Big-Five trait, including Extraversion, is scored with this instrument.
The same sentence lists neuroticism as an example of the trait scores returned by the Revised NEO Personality Inventory, showing that neuroticism is assessed with this scale.
Because the article presents the NEO-PI-R as “most commonly” used to measure the full Five-Factor Model, it necessarily includes Conscientiousness among the traits scored by the instrument.
By stating that the Revised NEO Personality Inventory operationalizes all five factors, the text indicates Agreeableness is one of the traits the measure captures.
The discussion of the NEO-PI-R as the routine way to assess the Five-Factor Model includes Openness to experience as one of the five scored dimensions.

measured_by: Full-scale online personality assessment based on FFM trade-off forced-choice scenarios
justification: Under Methods, the authors explain that they “designed a full-scale, online personality assessment” using 42 forced-choice scenarios, and that “by the conclusion of the assessment … allowed for the subsequent calculation of the participant's hierarchies of motivations,” showing this custom instrument is used to measure the hierarchy-of-motivations construct.
